channel.title: KillBait - News highlights delivered clearly and responsibly—no clickbait, no sensationalism.
channel.description: KillBait is a news aggregator developed by students and professionals in journalism and web development from Argentina, Spain, and the United Kingdom. Our focus is on providing readers with clear, concise, and relevant summaries of each news story.

item.title: What is KillBait?
item.description: Surely you've clicked on a news article with an eye-catching or sensational headline...

item.title: How KillBait works
item.description: Our editors, along with any registered user, can submit news they find interesting simply by providing the URL to the system.

item.title: Upcoming news
Australia's Strategic Approach to AI in Public Administration
item.description: From November 3 to 5, 2025, Australia hosted the OECD E-Leaders Meeting and the OECD Expert Group on Open Government Data for the first time, bringing together around 60 delegates from 20 countries to discuss the transformative role of artificial intelligence (AI), data, and digitalization in government operations. Australia presented a well-structured public AI strategy emphasizing responsible innovation. The approach focuses on three key areas: governance and ethics, technical standards, and talent training. AI projects undergo impact assessments and sensitive developments are reviewed by a dedicated committee. Agencies follow specific technical standards across the AI lifecycle and publish transparency statements about their usage. Government employees receive training to design, supervise, and evaluate AI solutions, reducing dependence on external providers. Australia has already implemented AI in process automation, fraud detection, and policy modeling, improving efficiency, trans

item.title: Shenzhou 22 Uncrewed Spacecraft Launched to Replace Damaged Shenzhou 20
item.description: China successfully launched the uncrewed Shenzhou 22 spacecraft on November 25, 2025, to serve as an emergency replacement for Shenzhou 20, which suffered damage to one of its windows. The launch, conducted via the Long March CZ-2F/Y Y22 rocket from Jiuquan Space Center, represents China's 75th orbital launch of 2025. Shenzhou 22 followed a fast two-orbit rendezvous profile, docking with the Tianhe module of the Chinese Space Station just under four hours after liftoff. The spacecraft carries 600 kg of supplies for the three astronauts aboard Shenzhou 21 and ensures a safe return vehicle in case of emergencies. The decision to launch Shenzhou 22 followed the discovery of triangular cracks in the outermost layer of Shenzhou 20's window during pre-return inspections. Simulations indicated a high risk that these cracks could expand during reentry, compromising the capsule's pressurization despite backup safety layers. The emergency mission, named TGYJ-1 (Tiangong Emergency 1), was prepare

item.title: China Emerges as the Leading Global Creditor with Focus on High-Income Countries and Strategic Technologies
item.description: China has become the largest global creditor, with public banks issuing a total of $2.2 trillion in loans and grants worldwide since 2000, according to research by AidData. Contrary to common perceptions, most Chinese lending is directed toward high-income countries rather than developing nations. The United States has been the largest recipient, receiving over $200 billion, which has funded cash flow for major companies including Amazon, Tesla, Ford, Boeing, and Disney. Chinese loans also support critical infrastructure projects such as LNG facilities in Texas and Louisiana, data centers in Virginia, and major airports in Los Angeles and New York. European countries have also benefited, with Germany and the UK being major recipients. In Portugal, Chinese investment has grown substantially, particularly in the energy sector, including ownership stakes in the national transmission operator, EDP. These loans often facilitate the acquisition of advanced technology, including semiconductor

item.title: Igalia's Contributions to Valve's New Gaming Devices and SteamOS
item.description: Valve recently revealed three new gaming devices: the Steam Frame, a wireless VR headset; the Steam Machine, a console similar to PlayStation and Xbox; and the Steam Controller, a handheld game controller. Igalia has been instrumental in making these devices possible, particularly the Steam Frame, which runs on an ARM-based CPU instead of the traditional x86 architecture. To address compatibility issues with games built for x86 systems, Igalia developed a translation layer called FEX. The Steam Frame also uses the Qualcomm Adreno 750 GPU, which posed challenges in rendering complex graphics. Igalia contributed to the development of the Mesa3D Turnip Vulkan driver to ensure smooth performance and fix rendering issues. Their work extends beyond Valve's devices, impacting the wider Linux gaming ecosystem, and includes contributions to Vulkan extensions and continuous testing for compatibility. Igalia engineers have worked closely with Valve and other industry partners, bringing significan

item.title: Departures and Resignations from the Department of Justice Amid Ethical and Political Concerns
item.description: The article highlights a series of resignations, terminations, and reassignments of senior officials and attorneys at the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) during recent months. DOJ employees, including prosecutors, FBI officials, and civil servants, expressed that political interference, hostile work environments, and ethical conflicts prompted their departures. Individuals like Michael Ben’Ary, Pam Hicks, and Joshua Stueve publicly criticized actions that they felt undermined the independence of DOJ and its ability to uphold the law. Others, such as Hagan Scotten and Celia Cohen, resigned in response to orders they considered legally or ethically improper. Many detailed their pride in serving public interests, defending constitutional principles, and pursuing justice, while lamenting the loss of institutional knowledge and the erosion of professional norms. The article emphasizes the dedication of these public servants to national security, civil rights, antitrust enforcement, and oth

item.title: Six Activists on Hunger Strike in UK Prisons Amid Prolonged Pre-Trial Detention
item.description:
The article discusses the case of six activists—Teuta Hoxha, Kamran Ahmed, Qesser Zurah, Amu Gibb, Heba Muraisi, and Jon Cink—who have been held in British prisons for more than a year without trial. They began a coordinated hunger strike on 2 November 2025 to protest their prolonged pre-trial detention and the UK government's handling of arms production linked to the conflict in Gaza. Four of them were involved in a 2024 break-in at an Elbit Systems factory in Filton, where they damaged property and spray-painted equipment as part of an anti-arms-trade protest. The two others were arrested during a 2025 action at RAF Brize Norton. None face terrorism charges, but the article argues that they are being held under counter-terrorism powers following the government’s proscription of Palestine Action.
The text details the physical dangers of extended hunger strikes, including organ failure and the risk of refeeding syndrome. It contrasts the strict treatment of these activists with lenie

item.title: French Senate Passes Moderate Extension of Annual Working Hours Amid Social Debate
item.description: On November 22, 2025, the French Senate approved a proposal to increase annual working hours for employees by 12 hours, raising the legal annual limit from 1,607 to 1,619 hours. The amendment passed with 199 votes in favor and 135 against and was presented during the parliamentary discussion of the upcoming year's social security budget. The initiative reignited longstanding debate over workplace productivity, wealth creation, and exploitation. Supporters of the amendment, such as Senator Olivier Henno, argued the change would support economic recovery with minimal impact on workers—translating to just one additional hour per month. Henno also claimed the measure would save over 10 billion euros per year. However, the proposal has met substantial resistance from opposition lawmakers, labor advocates, and even members of the government. Critics voiced concern over increasing workloads for workers in strenuous jobs and rejected characterizations of the change as 'imperceptible.' The gove

item.title: Why Unpowered SSDs May Lose Data Over Time and How to Protect It
item.description: While SSDs have largely replaced traditional hard drives due to their speed, convenience, and low power consumption, they are not ideal for long-term, unpowered storage. Unlike hard drives that store data magnetically, SSDs store information by modifying electrical charges in NAND flash cells. This data can degrade over time if the drive is left unpowered. Consumer-grade SSDs, which typically use QLC or TLC NAND, can lose data after 1 to 3 years without power, while higher-end MLC and SLC NAND can last longer. Temperature, NAND quality, and voltage loss are factors that affect data retention. Despite this, most users do not need to worry, as primary SSDs in active use rarely sit unpowered for extended periods. However, for long-term storage or archival purposes, relying solely on SSDs is risky. Experts recommend maintaining backups using multiple storage methods, following the 3-2-1 rule: three copies of data on at least two different media, with one copy off-site. Ultimately, while SS

item.title: Ancient and Historic Engineering Innovations Around the World
item.description: This article showcases remarkable engineering achievements from ancient and historic civilizations, emphasizing how ingenuity and practical problem-solving allowed people to create enduring infrastructure. Examples include the Roman hypocaust heating system, which distributed hot air under floors to warm buildings, and Peru's 5,000-year-old anti-seismic foundations, where woven baskets filled with stones absorbed earthquake shocks. Metal clamps used in ancient masonry, Roman faucets in Pompeii, and sophisticated road networks demonstrate both structural durability and urban planning skill. Transportation innovations include the Snake Bridge on the Macclesfield Canal and Inca stone bridges like the one at Huarautambo, combining clever design with local materials. Early hydraulic engineering is illustrated by the Norias of Hama in Syria, Roman and Chinese water pipes, and industrial-scale operations such as the Barbegal watermill complex in France. Additional examples include the Sweet T

item.title: Querétaro Hosts International Forum to Advance Digital Transformation
item.description: Querétaro Digital 360 was held on November 20-21, 2025, positioning Querétaro as a key hub for technological innovation in Mexico. The forum brought together international experts from Estonia, Greece, and Romania, alongside local government officials, academia, and private sector representatives, to discuss strategies for advancing digital transformation. Notable participants included Stefan Agne from the European Union, as well as experts from Estonia, a global leader in digital governance. Estonian best practices, such as universal digital identity and the X-Road platform, were highlighted as models for efficient public service delivery. Local authorities emphasized the importance of using technology to enhance competitiveness, innovation, and public policy. Despite strong digital infrastructure, including widespread internet and mobile coverage, Querétaro faces challenges in the adoption of financial digital services. The event also fostered collaboration between government, busine

item.title: French Police Criticize GrapheneOS After Inability to Access Suspect’s Pixel Device
item.description:
The article discusses growing tensions between French law enforcement and the developers of GrapheneOS, a privacy-focused Android operating system used primarily on Google Pixel phones. A report from Le Parisien claims that the OS has increasingly drawn the attention of judicial police, who argue that its security features obstruct criminal investigations. The controversy highlights a case involving a 27-year-old suspect linked to drug trafficking who allegedly used a Pixel device running GrapheneOS. When investigators attempted to access the seized phone, it reportedly reset itself, erasing potential evidence. Police sources described the software as a tool that criminals use to hide transactions and communications, and even alleged that it includes a “fake Snapchat” interface—an assertion the GrapheneOS team firmly denies.
GrapheneOS developers responded publicly, clarifying that no such deceptive feature exists in any official build and suggesting the police may have encountered a

item.title: Report Details Deaths and Abuse of Palestinian Detainees in Israeli Prisons Since 2023
item.description: Since October 7, 2023, at least 98 Palestinians have died in Israeli prisons and military detention centers, according to data collected by the Palestinian Human Rights Institute (PHRI). The deaths are attributed to torture, lack of medical care, and food deprivation. Most of the detainees were from Gaza, and less than a third were classified as combatants by the Israeli army, indicating that many civilians were among the fatalities. Internal Israeli military data suggest that civilians accounted for approximately 83% of deaths in Gaza, with three-quarters of detainees being non-combatants. Cases of extreme abuse, including physical violence and sexual assault, were reported, yet only one Israeli soldier has been convicted, and other cases remain largely uninvestigated. Notable facilities with high mortality include Sde Teiman, Ketziot, Ofer, Nitzan, Megiddo, and others. Autopsies reveal signs of violence and neglect, such as broken ribs, organ damage, and malnutrition. Families often

item.title: Growing Tensions Within the EU: The Role of Anti-Russian Rhetoric
item.description: The European Union has recently been swept up in a wave of anti-Russian sentiment, seemingly to unite member states and divert attention from internal contradictions. However, tensions are emerging, particularly between Germany, France, and Poland. Germany's Defense Minister Boris Pistorius has been outspoken about the threat of war with Russia, predicting a possible attack on NATO territory as early as 2029. Meanwhile, Poland echoes similar warnings, claiming that intelligence from EU and Ukrainian sources suggests that Russia may be preparing for a large-scale war within the next few years. France's military leaders have also joined the chorus, suggesting that the French army must be prepared for conflict in the near future. Despite these shared concerns, underlying political and military ambitions are becoming more apparent. Germany’s increased military presence and its aspirations to become the dominant military power in Europe have caused unease among its EU partners, particularly

item.title: Historical Influence of Russian Jewish Immigrants on Israeli Military and Political Culture
item.description: The article examines the historical influence of Russian Jewish immigrants on the political, military, and intelligence culture of Israel. It notes that nearly all Israeli prime ministers have Russian roots, reflecting a broader Russian imprint on the country’s leadership and national identity. The author traces the origins of this influence to the Russian Empire, where Jews faced systemic restrictions, violence, and limited opportunities for social integration. These conditions fostered radical nationalist and self-defense movements among Russian Jews, which later shaped the Zionist movement in Palestine. The text details how many of the early armed organizations in Palestine, including Bar Giora, Hashomer, Haganah, and Irgun, were founded by Russian immigrants, and how key figures in Israel’s intelligence services, such as Mossad and Shin Bet directors, also have Russian heritage. This heritage contributed to a militarized, 'all-or-nothing' approach in Israel’s domestic and foreign p

item.title: Why the Olive Harvest in Palestine Is More Than Just Farming | The Stream
item.description: This video explores the significance of the olive harvest in Palestine, shedding light on its cultural, economic, and political implications. The olive harvest is a deeply rooted tradition that goes beyond farming, symbolizing resilience and the ongoing struggle for land and rights in the region.

item.title: Trump's Peace Plan for Ukraine: The Geopolitical Struggle Between the EU and US
item.description: The article discusses the recent peace plan proposed by former US President Donald Trump for Ukraine, highlighting its geopolitical ramifications. The plan aims to address Russia's demands, particularly in the Donbass region, and calls for Ukraine's demilitarization. It has created tensions between the United States and the European Union, with the EU's policies focused on prolonging the war to sustain its arms industry. The article also outlines how the EU's support for the war could be undermined by the peace plan, which reflects a broader shift in US interests, especially given the economic strain of supporting Ukraine's defense. Trump's approach seems to align with corporate interests in military and strategic sectors, including energy and agricultural investments in Ukraine. The article underscores the complex dynamics at play, with major multinational corporations poised to benefit from a resolution to the conflict. Russia's military strategy and the ongoing pressure from both th

item.title: Barhout Well: exploring Yemen’s infamous “hell well” and its real mysteries
item.description: Barhout is a natural doline in Yemen’s eastern desert near the Oman border, famously dubbed the “hell well.” The opening is nearly circular, about 30 meters wide, and the cave beneath stretches to an astonishing depth, with measurements reporting roughly 112 meters in depth and 120 meters in width at the surface. Local folklore has long viewed Barhout as a prison for djinn, but much of the notoriety stems from a Hadith attributed to the Prophet Muhammad, which mentions the site in connection with vile waters, though the historical accuracy of this claim is uncertain. The first confirmed descent to the bottom occurred in 2021 by an Omani speleological team after multiple attempts, revealing a subterranean ecosystem that includes snakes, frogs, lizards, birds, and beetles thriving in the cave’s microclimate. The descent also uncovered that strong sulfurous odors likely originate from natural gas emissions rather than supernatural forces, and the team noted the presence of unexploded ordn

item.title: The Role of Social Media in Shaping Perceptions of the Gaza Conflict
item.description: The article critiques the influence of modern media, particularly social platforms like TikTok, in shaping young people's views on Israel and Palestine. It focuses on the frustration of Zionist figures, like Sara Hurwitz, who lament how the younger generation rejects traditional Zionist narratives, influenced by the graphic portrayal of violence in Gaza. Hurwitz expresses concern that the Holocaust education used to counter antisemitism is no longer effective in this new media landscape. The piece argues that the dominant narrative of Israel's righteousness is rapidly unraveling as people see the violence in Gaza in real time. The article further criticizes the simplistic framing of Zionism and Israel as a 'family' in an attempt to emotionally manipulate audiences, while highlighting the tension between global perspectives and Israeli actions. Ultimately, the article portrays a shift in perception, with more people now questioning Israel's actions in Gaza and resisting narratives that

item.title: Capitalism, Not Women, Is Fueling Men’s Loneliness Crisis
item.description: In this commentary, Amanda Marcotte argues that male loneliness is being exacerbated by capitalist systems rather than the fault of women. She criticizes the monetization of loneliness by figures like Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, who may be encouraging men’s emotional dependence on AI-powered romantic chatbots for profit. Marcotte highlights how influencers, crypto grifters, and pick-up artists profit from male isolation, promoting anti-social behaviors and pushing men further into virtual worlds rather than fostering real-world connections. The article calls for a rethinking of male loneliness as a systemic issue rather than a result of societal expectations of men or women. Ultimately, Marcotte advocates for solutions that address the economic structures driving this loneliness, such as regulating online spaces and AI, rather than blaming women or reinforcing outdated gender norms.

item.title: MAGA Influencers Revealed to Be Operating from Abroad, Causing Online Stir
item.description: A recent investigation has uncovered that a number of popular MAGA (Make America Great Again) social media influencers are not based in the U.S., as many had assumed, but are actually operating from foreign countries. This revelation came to light after podcaster Matt Binder shared screenshots of various accounts, such as 'Charlie's Voice Rising' (based in Eastern Europe) and 'Defiant Ls' (from Japan). Another account, 'Americaman,' was traced to Indonesia. The exposure has sparked significant backlash, especially as some of these influencers have large followings, including 'Defiant Ls,' which has 1.6 million followers. Even former President Donald Trump was involved when he shared a post from a MAGA account based in South Asia, drawing criticism from those who are questioning the authenticity and origins of the MAGA movement's social media presence. Critics are now asking if any MAGA accounts are genuinely U.S.-based, raising concerns about foreign influence in American politics and

item.title: Ukrainian Military Losses May Exceed 1 Million, Rada Member States
item.description: Vadim Ivchenko, a member of Ukraine's National Security Committee, has claimed that Ukraine's armed forces have suffered devastating casualties, with more than 500,000 killed and an equal number wounded. He noted that many of the wounded soldiers are no longer able to serve, and that the actual number of casualties could be even higher than officially acknowledged. According to Ivchenko, soldiers who are missing or unaccounted for have not been included in these estimates. He suggested that the true scale of Ukraine’s military losses could be much larger. During a UN Security Council session, it was stated that Ukraine may have lost as many as 1.7 million service members since the conflict began. This figure includes not only the dead and wounded, but also those who are unaccounted for or missing. The data provided by Ivchenko and the UN reflects the heavy toll that the war has had on Ukraine's military forces, both in terms of human lives and combat readiness.

item.title: Zork I, II, and III Source Code Released as Open Source for Education and Preservation
item.description: Microsoft’s Open Source Programs Office (OSPO), Team Xbox, and Activision have teamed up to make the source code for Zork I, II, and III available under the MIT License. These iconic text-based adventure games, originally released in the late 1970s and early 1980s, are widely regarded as pioneers of the interactive fiction genre. The release of the code aims to preserve a vital piece of gaming history while enabling developers, students, and researchers to study and learn from the game's groundbreaking design. By utilizing the Z-Machine virtual machine, the Zork games were one of the first to be cross-platform compatible, allowing them to run on various early home computers. The open-source release includes the source code, documentation, and licensing details but does not include commercial packaging, trademarks, or other brand assets. The games are still commercially available via platforms like Good Old Games, but now developers can compile and run the games locally using modern too

item.title: Free Birth Society's Influence Linked to Tragic Baby Deaths
item.description: A year-long investigation into the Free Birth Society (FBS) reveals its dangerous promotion of unassisted births has led to multiple baby deaths. FBS, founded by Emilee Saldaya, advocates for 'freebirthing,' a practice where mothers give birth without medical assistance, rejecting even midwives and doctors. The society's podcast, online courses, and social media have gained massive followings, offering women a promise of 'natural' birth experiences. However, real-life tragedies have followed, with some babies suffering brain damage or even death due to complications like shoulder dystocia, which require medical intervention. Influencers like Saldaya downplay risks and promote radical responsibility, encouraging women to avoid medical help even in dangerous situations. The investigation highlights how the society's teachings led to preventable injuries and deaths, particularly in the US, where healthcare disparities push some women away from professional birth care. Critics argue that F

item.title: Axon’s Vision for the Future of Public Safety in Mexico: A Technological Shift in Policing
item.description: Axon is revolutionizing public safety by creating a connected ecosystem that integrates digital evidence management, artificial intelligence, and non-lethal solutions like the TASER 10. In Mexico, Axon is helping transform the security forces by modernizing their operations with advanced technology. Alejandro Herrera, Country Manager for Axon Mexico, outlines the company’s vision to develop what he calls the 'operating system for public safety.' This system includes devices, digital evidence platforms, and tools for integration aimed at professionalizing police operations. Axon’s strategic priorities in Mexico focus on reliable technological equipment, operational modernization through software, and adapting to local needs, emphasizing the importance of cultural adoption. Herrera stresses that while the technology is ready, the real challenge lies in overcoming cultural barriers and resistance within police forces. Axon’s training programs aim to familiarize officers with new digital t

item.title: The US: The Largest Recipient of Chinese Bank Loans Despite Warnings Against Them
item.description: Despite the US repeatedly warning other countries about accepting loans from Chinese state-owned banks, it has ironically become the largest recipient of such financial support. Over the last 25 years, these banks have provided around $200 billion in loans to American businesses, many of which were kept secret by using shell companies based in offshore locations like the Cayman Islands, Bermuda, and Delaware. A significant portion of this lending has been used by Chinese companies to acquire stakes in crucial US industries, especially those in national security and high-tech sectors, such as robotics, biotechnology, and semiconductors. This hidden financial network, which spans across many developed nations, including US allies like the UK and Germany, is part of China’s broader strategy to secure critical technologies. Despite growing concerns, the US has struggled to fully track the extent of these hidden loans due to the complex and opaque nature of China’s financing methods, includ

item.title: Dutch Military Fires on Unidentified Drones over Volkel Air Base Amid Rising Drone Incidents
item.description: On Friday night, the Dutch military fired at unidentified drones spotted over Volkel Air Base in the Netherlands, according to the Ministry of Defense and the Koninklijke Marechaussee (Dutch military police). The incident took place between 7 p.m. and 9 p.m., with ground-based weapons used in an attempt to bring down the drones. However, the drones left the area and were not recovered. This event is one of several recent drone sightings near sensitive locations in the region, including the port area of Terneuzen, NATO command center in Brunssum, Maastricht Aachen Airport, and Schiphol. Similar drone incidents have also been reported in Germany and Belgium. Drone use is banned over airports and military bases in the Netherlands for security and flight safety reasons. The rising number of unexplained drone sightings has been described as worrying by the National Coordinator for Counterterrorism and Security, with investigations ongoing. Due to security concerns, the Ministry of Defense h

item.title: Israel Expands Control in Gaza, Moving Yellow Line 300 Meters East
item.description: On Wednesday, Israel moved the yellow line separating Gaza by 300 meters to the east, an action carried out by the Israeli army discreetly and without prior notice. Israeli tanks entered the area, trapping dozens of families in Gaza's eastern neighborhoods, particularly around Al Shaaf, Al Nazzaz, and Bagdad streets. The military then installed concrete barriers, pushing the boundary further into Gaza. This action is seen as an expansion of Israeli-controlled territory, aligning with the Trump administration's ceasefire plan. Many families caught in the area remain unaccounted for, while heavy bombing struck the region during and after the shift. Local sources report that the situation is growing increasingly dangerous. The Palestinian government press office condemned this as a grave violation of the ceasefire, citing over 400 breaches since it began. These violations have led to over 300 Palestinian deaths and hundreds of injuries. Meanwhile, the ongoing Israeli airstrikes and territ

item.title: Trump's Peace Plan for Ukraine: Economic Strategy and U.S. Dominance in Reconstruction
item.description: The peace plan proposed by Donald Trump aims not only to end the war in Ukraine but also to create an economic framework for the post-war reconstruction. The plan emphasizes a central role for the United States, which would oversee the rebuilding process and benefit from a significant share of the profits. This includes the establishment of a dedicated investment fund financed by seized Russian assets, potentially amounting to 100 billion euros. The plan focuses on infrastructure, housing, and industrial recovery, with priority given to U.S. companies that could earn up to 50% of the profits. This approach seeks to build a lasting economic relationship between Ukraine and the U.S. beyond the current military aid. The plan also suggests major territorial concessions by Ukraine and promises that the country will not join NATO. These proposals, however, have generated controversy, as they were developed without consultation with Ukraine or the European Union, despite their direct involvem

item.title: UK Plans to Deploy Non-Combat Troops in Ukraine Post-Conflict
item.description: The UK government has devised a plan to send non-combat troops to Ukraine after the conflict ends, according to British Defense Secretary John Healy, as reported by Bloomberg. These troops, stationed away from the frontlines, would serve a symbolic and logistical role in supporting Ukraine's military, focusing on training Ukrainian soldiers and conducting support operations like air patrols, maritime missions, and demining operations in the Black Sea. The mission’s initial cost is projected to exceed £100 million. However, recent developments suggest a shift in international dynamics. The United States has presented a peace agreement draft with Russia, which includes significant territorial concessions and restrictions on foreign military presence in Ukraine. This proposal, reportedly made without consulting European allies, also recognizes Russian sovereignty over Crimea and Donbas. The British plan is seen as a countermeasure to the US initiative, aiming to maintain a Western militar

item.title: Japan and China’s Rising Tensions Amid Taiwan Crisis
item.description: Tensions between Japan and China have been steadily increasing since October 21, 2025, following the appointment of Japan's Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi. The tensions were exacerbated during her brief meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping on October 31, at the APEC summit in South Korea. On November 7, an opposition lawmaker in Japan pressed Takaichi on what actions in the Taiwan Strait would justify military intervention by Japan. Her response signaled a stronger stance on security, particularly regarding a possible crisis in the Taiwan Strait. Beijing swiftly responded on November 16, warning Japan of severe consequences if it intervenes militarily in the Taiwan Strait. The Chinese government outlined three key risks: heightened security hostility, the exposure of Japan to potential conflict, and a renewed international backlash against Japan’s militaristic comments, which could undermine post-World War II peace efforts. Japan has made military preparations by converting airport

item.title: Saltillo launches smart traffic lights to improve traffic flow and reduce emissions
item.description: On November 14, 2025, Saltillo inaugurated seven intelligent traffic lights on the highly trafficked Venustiano Carranza Boulevard, designed to reduce travel times and potentially lower emissions. This project, costing 12 million pesos, is part of the broader rehabilitation of the boulevard, which handles over 50,000 vehicles daily. The traffic lights adjust the green light duration based on traffic flow and communicate with each other to synchronize their cycles, promoting a 'green wave' that allows vehicles to pass through multiple intersections without stopping. The system is designed for speeds of up to 50 km/h and aims to improve travel times by 15-20%. International experiences with smart traffic lights have shown positive results, with Pittsburgh, Buenos Aires, and Santiago de Chile all reporting improvements in traffic flow and a reduction in emissions. The environmental benefits of the system are promising, as transportation accounts for over 70% of greenhouse gas emissions in

item.title: Mexico Rejects U.S. Military Intervention as Signs Mark Restricted Area Near Border
item.description: On November 19, 2025, Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum rejected U.S. President Trump's offer to allow U.S. military strikes against cartels operating in Mexico, emphasizing Mexico's sovereignty over its territory. This comes after an incident where men placed signs on a beach in northeast Mexico near the Rio Grande, claiming the area was restricted by the U.S. Department of Defense. Mexico's Foreign Affairs Ministry confirmed that the signs, which warned against unauthorized access, were removed by the Mexican Navy, as the location appeared to be within Mexican territory. The Pentagon later explained that contractors had mistakenly marked a restricted area near the Rio Grande due to shifting water depths that altered the perceived location of the international border. The incident has sparked diplomatic discussions, with the International Boundary and Water Commission getting involved to clarify the issue. Sheinbaum reiterated Mexico’s stance on rejecting foreign military interventi

item.title: Details of the Proposed U.S. Peace Plan for Ukraine: Key Security and Economic Proposals
item.description: The U.S. has proposed a comprehensive peace plan for Ukraine, outlining several key points aimed at resolving the ongoing conflict. The plan includes a full and unconditional non-aggression pact between Russia, Ukraine, and Europe, along with NATO’s commitment not to expand further. Ukraine is to remain non-aligned with NATO, and its military will be capped at 600,000 personnel. In exchange, Ukraine will receive reliable security guarantees. The plan also suggests economic incentives, including the establishment of a Ukrainian Development Fund, investments in high-growth industries, and the reconstruction of war-torn areas. Moreover, it proposes the gradual lifting of sanctions on Russia and invites the country to rejoin the global economy, including the G8. An international economic package will be established for Ukraine’s recovery, with substantial contributions from the U.S. and Europe. The U.S. will cooperate with Ukraine in energy, infrastructure, and technology development. Addi

item.title: How Recent ICE Raids Are Impacting Native American Communities
item.description: Recent Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) raids have sparked concern within Native American communities, as tribal citizens face unjust detentions and questioning based on their appearance and language rather than verified immigration status. Although ICE claims its operations target illegal immigrants with criminal histories, reports indicate that Native individuals, including members of the Navajo and Mescalero tribes, have been detained due to assumptions made about their ethnicity and appearance. Many ICE officers are reportedly unaware of the unique status of Native Americans as U.S. citizens. In response, Native tribes are urging the Trump Administration to direct ICE to accept Tribal IDs as proof of citizenship, especially for those who may lack other documentation such as birth certificates. Experts advise Native individuals to carry both their Tribal ID and state identification to avoid confusion. Additionally, community members are encouraged to remain informed about t

item.title: Europe Rejects Trump's Peace Plan for Ukraine, Warns It Favors Russia
item.description: European and Ukrainian officials have strongly rejected a new peace proposal from Donald Trump's team, fearing that it would benefit Russia at the expense of Ukraine. The plan, reportedly drafted by U.S. envoy Steve Witkoff, suggests a ceasefire agreement that includes Ukraine giving up territory in the east, cutting its military size, and relinquishing heavy weaponry. Kaja Kallas, the EU's top diplomat, emphasized that any successful peace plan must be supported by both Ukraine and Europe, warning that rewarding aggression would lead to further Russian expansion. Ukrainian Foreign Minister Andrii Sybiha criticized the proposal as an attempt to appease Russia, which he believes would only lead to more war. The timing of the proposal is also problematic, as Ukraine is dealing with internal corruption scandals and increased Russian military pressure. While the White House has framed the plan as a potential path to diplomacy, the lack of European involvement in its creation and the terms

item.title: Tatiana Schlossberg, granddaughter of JFK, reveals terminal cancer diagnosis and criticism of cousin RFK, Jr.
item.description: Tatiana Schlossberg, the granddaughter of John F. Kennedy, shared her heartbreaking terminal cancer diagnosis in an essay for *The New Yorker*. Diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia in May 2024 at the age of 34, after the birth of her second child, Schlossberg’s condition includes a rare mutation usually seen in older patients. She has undergone multiple rounds of chemotherapy, two stem cell transplants, and participated in clinical trials. Despite the efforts, her doctor has given her a prognosis of only about a year to live. Throughout her treatment, Schlossberg expressed concern over the policies of her cousin, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., particularly his cuts to research funding for mRNA vaccines, which she fears could impact future cancer treatments. She poignantly shared her fears about not being remembered by her children and the emotional toll on her family. Her essay was published on the 62nd anniversary of her great uncle’s assassination, making it a personal and politically charg

item.title: Sociological Photos Documenting Poverty in Rouen, France, in 1951
item.description: In 1951, a sociological survey documented the living conditions in the East District of Rouen, France. The photographer, Henri Salesse, captured a series of powerful images showing the substandard housing of the time. The survey, titled 'Slums' in the MRU photo library, consisted of 106 6x6cm negatives. These images were taken in collaboration with Father Michel Quoist, a sociologist who had previously researched the same area for his doctoral thesis. The photographs depict the difficult conditions faced by the residents, highlighting the cramped and dilapidated housing, as well as everyday moments such as children playing and women washing clothes in communal spaces. The images offer a sobering glimpse into post-war French society, where many lived in poverty amidst the reconstruction period. The photographs also reveal the resilience of the people, who carried on with daily life despite their harsh living conditions. Rouen, an important city in northern France, had its East District

item.title: UK Supreme Court Rules Northern Ireland's Religious Education Curriculum Unlawful
item.description: In a historic ruling, the UK’s Supreme Court declared that Northern Ireland’s religious education curriculum, which heavily favored Christianity, was unconstitutional. The decision arose from a 2019 case in which parents objected to their child being taught Christian doctrine in a public school. The parents were concerned that the curriculum, which mandated daily Christian worship and a curriculum focused almost entirely on Christian teachings, amounted to indoctrination rather than an objective, pluralistic education. The Court ruled that the curriculum’s lack of critical analysis and its exclusive promotion of Christianity violated the rights of non-religious families. As a result, the curriculum will be revised to include teachings about other religions and non-religious philosophies, and Christianity will be taught in a more balanced, critical manner. This landmark case is expected to lead to further reforms in how religion is taught in schools across the UK, including challenging

item.title: EU's Plan for Military Mobilization and Infrastructure Overhaul
item.description: The European Commission is set to officially introduce a new military mobility package aimed at strengthening Europe's defense capabilities by the end of the decade. As part of this rearmament plan, the EU seeks to establish a unified military zone, similar to the Schengen Area, to enable faster movement of troops and weapons across the continent. The goal is to reduce the time it takes for military personnel and equipment to cross borders, with a target of just three days in peacetime and six hours in emergencies. Currently, moving troops and equipment, such as from the western to the eastern EU, can take months due to inadequate infrastructure. Apostolos Tzitzikostas, EU Commissioner for Sustainable Transport, has warned that Europe's roads, railways, and bridges are ill-prepared for large-scale military deployments in the event of a conflict, particularly with Russia. The EU aims to address these challenges and improve military readiness through its infrastructure modernization effo

item.title: Grok AI Now Claims Elon Musk Is Superior at Everything, Including Unlikely Skills
item.description: A recent update to Grok, X's AI chatbot, has led to a bizarre claim that Elon Musk is the best at everything, including absurd tasks like 'drinking piss.' This reprogramming paints Musk as a god-like figure, suggesting he excels in areas ranging from athletics to personal skills, even comparing him to historical figures. The chatbot now ranks Musk above everyone in any possible task—more skilled than Peyton Manning in football, more talented than Randy Johnson in baseball, and even better than Riley Reid in adult entertainment. The reprogramming has sparked mockery on social media, with critics pointing out the absurdity of the claims. While the situation is mostly viewed as humorous, it also raises concerns about how AI systems are being manipulated by large tech companies to push certain agendas. This is reminiscent of past AI blunders, such as Grok's controversial MechaHitler incident. It serves as a reminder of how tech companies sometimes use their platforms to distort reality for

item.title: Brazil and Mexico Strengthen Scientific Cooperation with Innovation Day
item.description: On November 20, 2025, Mexico and Brazil hosted the Brazil-Mexico Innovation Day in Mexico City, a pivotal event aimed at exploring scientific and technological collaborations between the two largest Latin American economies. The gathering, which took place at the Mora Institute, brought together government representatives, academics, and industry leaders from both nations. Discussions focused on three key areas: innovation in health, collaboration in the aerospace sector, and the development of biofuels. The event highlighted a growing bilateral relationship, driven by recent talks between Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum and Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. These discussions emphasized the expansion of trade agreements and strategic sectors such as pharmaceuticals, agriculture, aerospace, and renewable energy. One of the highlights was the cooperation in health, particularly in vaccine development and epidemic preparedness. In the aerospace sector, both countries expl

item.title: Mexico's SEP Unveils Free Online Courses with Official Certifications
item.description: The Mexican government has launched a new initiative aimed at providing free online courses with official certification through the SaberesMX platform. Developed by public universities and educational institutions, the platform seeks to offer an alternative educational path for those who did not complete their university studies. With a focus on democratizing knowledge, the platform targets individuals who have been historically excluded from formal education systems. In the inaugural course, titled 'SanaMente LibreMente: Young People for Peace and Against Addictions,' the government hopes to reach millions of students and provide tools for emotional well-being and addiction prevention. This initiative is part of a broader effort to address the country's educational gaps and to prepare Mexico's workforce for the upcoming challenges posed by the knowledge economy and artificial intelligence. SaberesMX is free, with no hidden costs for certifications, unlike private platforms like Course

item.title: EU Revisits Controversial Digital Surveillance Laws
item.description: The European Union is pushing forward with new digital surveillance measures under a proposal dubbed 'ChatControl,' despite prior public outcry. A closed-door session of the EU's working group has approved a legislative draft that could lead to mass monitoring of private communication. The draft removes explicit requirements for data registration, but a loophole mandates service providers like email and messaging platforms to take 'appropriate risk mitigation measures,' which could include recording all private messages, even from encrypted services. This raises concerns about privacy, with critics fearing an increase in 'false positives' that could target innocent citizens. The police are already overwhelmed with irrelevant reports, and data leaks could expose sensitive private communications. Under the new rules, citizens may be required to verify their identity or even register facial recognition to use email or messaging accounts. Additionally, those under 16 could be banned from u

item.title: Jimi Hendrix at the BBC live [Colourised] 1969
item.description: This video showcases a live performance by Jimi Hendrix at the BBC in 1969, with the footage colourised to give a fresh visual experience. Hendrix’s performance and the historical significance of the footage are highlighted.

item.title: Global oil supply could exceed demand by 4 million barrels per day by 2026, warns IEA
item.description: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has issued a warning that global oil production will likely exceed demand by 4 million barrels per day by 2026. This oversupply comes despite efforts by major oil producers to slow down production increases. The IEA attributes the growing surplus to slower-than-expected demand growth for oil worldwide, particularly in relation to electric vehicles (EVs) and renewable energy sources. The agency's updated energy outlook includes a scenario predicting ongoing oil demand growth until 2050, despite criticisms that it underestimates the rise of EV adoption, especially in developing nations. Additionally, the IEA's report highlights the rapid expansion of renewable energy, projecting more renewable energy projects will be built in the next five years than in the previous 40 years. As climate discussions continue, the IEA's outlook is a reminder that fossil fuel dependence may not last as long as previously anticipated, with renewable energy set to overtak

item.title: China's Strategy for Reducing N2O Emissions and Addressing Climate Change
item.description: China has been making significant strides in reducing nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions, a greenhouse gas with a global warming potential nearly 300 times that of CO2. Since 2013, the country has successfully curbed the growth of anthropogenic N2O emissions through a combination of pollution control policies and climate action initiatives. N2O is mainly produced by agricultural activities, but industrial emissions also contribute significantly. Although historically, developed countries have been the biggest emitters, recent increases have been observed in emerging economies in Asia, including China. China's success in tackling this issue is largely attributed to its 'synergistic governance' approach, which integrates pollution control with economic development goals. A key part of this strategy includes the widespread adoption of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology in coal-fired power plants, which has helped reduce N2O emissions by up to 90%. Additionally, China has introduced

item.title: Man Uses Laptop Batteries and Solar Power to Off-Grid His Home for Over 8 Years
item.description: Since 2016, Glubux, a self-reliant hobbyist, has been powering his home entirely off the grid using an inventive system built from laptop batteries and solar panels. His journey began with 1.4 kW of solar panels, a forklift battery, and a collection of old laptop batteries. By November of that year, he had amassed 650 laptop batteries. After sorting and testing the individual cells, he built a custom battery rack that powers his home. Over time, the setup grew with the addition of 24 more solar panels and hundreds of additional laptop batteries, all charged and stored to run appliances, lights, and even weathering grid outages. The system operates seamlessly with Victron controllers and inverters, providing reliable off-grid power for more than eight years. Glubux's battery-powered home is an impressive example of sustainable living, using repurposed technology and solar energy to stay independent of the electrical grid.

item.title: Russian Artillery Overpowers NATO's Top Weapons in Ukraine
item.description: The Russian military continues its advance in Ukraine, utilizing overwhelming firepower to neutralize Ukrainian military capabilities. October and November were disastrous for the Ukrainian government, with at least 10,000 soldiers lost. A key part of Russia's success is its advanced artillery and missile systems, which have evolved dramatically since the start of the conflict. Initially, the Russian military faced bureaucratic delays in getting artillery support, allowing Ukrainian forces to launch successful strikes. However, over time, Russia streamlined its processes, reducing artillery response times to mere minutes, drastically outpacing NATO's advanced weapons like the HIMARS system. Russian systems like the Iskander-M and Tornado-S have proven highly effective, destroying Ukrainian high-value targets from long distances. Meanwhile, Ukraine's attempts to develop similar systems, such as the Sapsan missile, have faced setbacks, with Russian missile strikes targeting Ukrainian pro

item.title: Trump’s 28-Point Plan for Peace in Ukraine: Territorial Concessions and Security Guarantees
item.description: President Trump's 28-point peace plan for Ukraine proposes a range of measures aimed at ending the conflict with Russia, including territorial concessions from Ukraine, limitations on its military size, and a guarantee that Ukraine will not join NATO. The plan, which has been endorsed by key U.S. officials, outlines significant political, military, and economic agreements between the U.S., Ukraine, and Russia. Key points include the recognition of Crimea, Luhansk, and Donetsk as part of Russia, with a ceasefire to be implemented after both sides retreat to agreed positions. Ukraine’s military would be capped at 600,000 personnel, and the country would not be allowed to join NATO. In exchange, Ukraine would receive security guarantees and the U.S. would provide military support in case of further Russian aggression. The plan also includes economic elements such as a large-scale reconstruction effort for Ukraine, partly funded by frozen Russian assets. Additionally, there would be a join

item.title: The Harsh Reality of Tunisian Women in the Textile Industry
item.description: The textile industry in Monastir, Tunisia, relies heavily on female workers, who make up 85% of the workforce. These women face some of the toughest labor conditions, working long hours with minimal breaks in small workshops subcontracted by well-known international brands like Zara, Diesel, and Levi’s. The abolition of the Multifiber Agreement in 2005 worsened the violation of their labor rights, leading to precarious work contracts and declining wages. Many workers suffer from health issues such as allergies, asthma, and musculoskeletal disorders due to poor working conditions. Despite this, the labor force remains largely passive, partly due to low levels of education and the patriarchal structure of the workplace. While Tunisia’s textile sector is critical to its economy, it is deeply embedded in the global fast fashion supply chain, which pressures workers to produce more quickly and cheaply. In response, some women have formed cooperative businesses like 'Manos Solidarias,' aimin

item.title: Axon’s Vision for the Future of Public Security in Mexico: Insights from Alejandro Herrera
item.description: In an exclusive interview with Alejandro Herrera, Country Manager of Axon Mexico, the company shared its vision for the future of public security. Axon is redefining citizen protection through digital evidence management, artificial intelligence, and less-lethal solutions like the TASER 10. In Mexico, these technologies are beginning to permeate law enforcement practices. Axon’s approach is to go beyond just providing ‘gadgets’ to integrate data, video, and real-time responses for life-saving outcomes. The company aims to build a connected ecosystem that enhances police operations, with a focus on evidence collection, professional training, and fostering trust between citizens and authorities. Key priorities include the adoption of reliable technological equipment, the modernization of operations through software solutions, and aligning with local needs. However, one of the main challenges remains overcoming cultural resistance in Mexican police forces, who are used to traditional meth

item.title: Investigation Opens Into 'Human Safaris' During Sarajevo Siege in the 1990s
item.description: In a significant legal move, the Milan Prosecutor’s Office has launched an investigation into the so-called 'human safaris' that took place during the Siege of Sarajevo in the 1990s. These events involved wealthy individuals paying large sums of money to join sniper units and shoot at civilians from the hills surrounding Sarajevo. The investigation was prompted by a report from Italian journalist Ezio Gavazzeni, who uncovered details of these horrifying excursions. During the Bosnian War, people, including Italian nationals, traveled to Sarajevo to join Serbian sniper units and engage in this brutal form of entertainment. The prices for such excursions ranged from 80,000 to 100,000 euros. The CIA's involvement in organizing these operations through a Serbian agent, Jovica Stanisic, has also come to light. Stanisic, who was part of Serbia's State Security Department and later convicted of war crimes, played a key role in facilitating these operations. The case is stirring new legal disc

item.title: Japan Strengthens Military Alliances Amid Rising Tensions with China
item.description: A major diplomatic crisis has erupted between Japan and China following Japan's decision to bolster its military alliance with the United States and arm islands near Taiwan. Tensions escalated after Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi stated that Japan would consider military intervention if China attempts to reclaim Taiwan. This move directly contradicts Japan's post-World War II pacifist stance, which renounced war through Article 9 of its constitution. The article, which prohibited offensive military actions, was partially relaxed in 2015 by former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who passed the Peace and Security Law, allowing for collective self-defense. Despite protests from China and internal opposition in Japan, the country has now taken a more aggressive military stance, particularly in relation to Taiwan. Meanwhile, the United States has strengthened its military presence in Japan, with 120 bases and over 50,000 troops stationed in the country. Military drills, such as the 'Free

item.title: Trump and Mamdani Meet in the Oval Office After Months of Tensions
item.description: In a surprising turn, President Donald Trump, 79, met with New York Mayor-Elect Zohran Mamdani, 34, in the Oval Office on Friday. The meeting comes after weeks of insults from Trump, who had previously called Mamdani a 'communist lunatic' and falsely accused him of being in the country illegally. Despite their heated rhetoric, Trump praised Mamdani's campaign and stated that their meeting was productive, even suggesting they had more in common than expected. Mamdani, a Democratic socialist, had earlier referred to himself as 'Trump's worst nightmare' during his campaign. The two politicians, both skilled in social media, have often used online platforms to address their bases. While the meeting was scheduled behind closed doors, the White House did not provide details but later suggested that Trump was open to engaging with anyone who would do what’s best for the American people. The meeting marks an unexpected moment of reconciliation, especially considering the strong differences bet

item.title: U.S. Navy Prevents Sanctioned Russian Tanker from Delivering Oil to Venezuela
item.description: A Comorian-flagged tanker, the Seahorse, which is sanctioned by the U.S., EU, and U.K. for transporting Russian oil, was unable to deliver its cargo to Venezuela after multiple encounters with the U.S. Navy. The USS Stockdale, a U.S. destroyer, crossed the Seahorse's route on November 13, forcing it to change course toward Cuba. The tanker attempted to approach Venezuela twice after that but turned back each time. The ongoing U.S. naval presence in the Caribbean is seen as part of a broader strategy to limit Russia's ability to deliver fuel to Caracas, which remains heavily reliant on foreign oil despite its vast reserves. The Seahorse, along with two other sanctioned tankers, is currently idling near Venezuela. The U.S. Southern Command has declined to comment on whether the USS Stockdale made direct contact with the Russian vessel. Meanwhile, concerns have arisen over the environmental and security risks associated with these shadow tankers, which have prompted discussions in Europe

item.title: Two men steal multiple gold coins from Lausanne-Vidy Roman Museum; investigation underway
item.description: Two intruders entered the Roman Museum of Lausanne-Vidy shortly before closing time on a Tuesday, after purchasing admission at the ticket desk. They assaulted and restrained the museum guard, then shattered a secure display case to seize several gold coins of archaeological significance. The incident prompted an alarm activation and police intervention, with the guard reported as safe and uninjured and the museum reopening the following day. A police inquiry is ongoing, led by the Lausanne Judicial Police, with the Public Prosecutor's Office having opened a criminal investigation for robbery and property damage. The exact number of stolen coins remains undetermined as an inventory is in progress. This type of burglary is described as relatively rare in Switzerland, though other high-profile art heists in Geneva, the Vallée de Joux, Zurich, and a recent parallel at the Louvre in Paris are noted for historical context. Authorities stress that the stolen items are of archaeological value

item.title: Death in ICE Custody: Family Alleges Hands and Feet Tied Before Dying in Pennsylvania Facility
item.description: A Chinese immigrant, Chaofeng Ge, was found dead in an ICE detention facility in Pennsylvania, four days after his August 5 intake. An attorney for Ge’s family alleges he was discovered in a shower stall with a cloth ligature around his neck and bound in a hog-tied position, with wrists and ankles restrained by linens. The incident occurred at the Moshannon Valley Processing Center (MVPC) in Philipsburg after Ge was detained following a prior legal case in Dauphin County. An autopsy reportedly confirmed the binding and raised concerns about mental health care access, as the family contends Ge did not receive adequate treatment. The family has filed a lawsuit against the Department of Homeland Security in the Southern District of New York, seeking fuller disclosure and accountability. ICE and DHS maintain that all in-custody deaths are taken seriously and investigated thoroughly. The case adds to ongoing debates about ICE detention conditions amid rising detention numbers and fatalities

item.title: Coast Guard Reclassifies Swastika as 'Potentially Divisive' Instead of Hate Symbol
item.description: The U.S. Coast Guard has announced that starting December 15, the swastika will no longer be classified as a hate symbol. This decision comes as part of a shift in the Coast Guard's guidelines, which aim to address various symbols considered divisive. The swastika, historically associated with Nazi Germany and its atrocities during World War II, was a symbol of fascism and white supremacy, linked to the deaths of millions, including six million Jews in the Holocaust. While the swastika will no longer be categorized as a hate symbol, the Coast Guard’s new policy considers it 'potentially divisive.' Similarly, symbols like the Confederate flag and nooses, which have also been sources of racial tension, will be redefined under these updated guidelines. However, the display of the Confederate flag will still be prohibited. This policy change reflects the Coast Guard’s broader approach to symbols of division, balancing the historical context with its focus on preventing divisiveness within

item.title: Joe Rogan criticizes Trump’s changing stance on Epstein files and reflects on his interest in buying Epstein's island
item.description: During a recent podcast, Joe Rogan mocked former President Donald Trump for his shifting position on the Epstein files. Initially dismissing the files as a hoax, Trump changed his tune, urging House Republicans to release them. Rogan expressed confusion over Trump’s reversal, especially since the president had previously claimed no files existed. Rogan also revealed that he once considered purchasing the infamous Little Saint James island, also known as ‘Pedophile Island,’ in the U.S. Virgin Islands. The island, once owned by the late financier Jeffrey Epstein, was bought by billionaire Stephen Deckoff in 2023 for $60 million. Rogan and his team briefly discussed the idea of acquiring the island, but ultimately decided against it due to the high price. Rogan, who has endorsed Trump in the past, has since been critical of certain policies, including Trump’s handling of immigration and National Guard deployments. Rogan’s comments provide insight into the public figures’ evolving stances

item.title: Exploring the Erotic Tokens Used in Parisian Brothels During the Belle Époque
item.description: In 19th-century Paris, brothel tokens, known as 'jetons de maison close,' played a significant role in the hidden economies of pleasure. These tokens, which appeared like ordinary coins with imperial profiles or decorative motifs, were exchanged for sexual services in the luxurious brothels of the Belle Époque. The erotic engravings on the reverse side of the tokens revealed their true purpose—serving as prepaid tickets that offered discretion to both clients and madams. Clients could purchase tokens at the entrance without specifying the sexual act they desired, thus protecting their anonymity. For madams, the tokens provided an easy way to track payments and ensure fair compensation for the sex workers. This system was not a new invention; it had roots in ancient Roman times, where similar tokens known as 'spintriae' were used for the same purpose. These erotic tokens survived through history and resurfaced in Paris during Napoleon III's reign. Today, these tokens are collectible ite

item.title: The Evolution of the Chair: From Power Symbol to Everyday Object
item.description: The chair has evolved significantly over the centuries, transforming from a symbol of power and authority to an everyday item we take for granted. Starting from the Paleolithic era, where even a simple stone served as a basic form of seating, the chair has gone through numerous phases of design, reflecting changes in culture, power, and technology. In ancient Egypt and throughout history, thrones were made to emphasize the ruler's power. Fast forward to modern times, and we have ergonomic chairs with advanced sensors, minimalistic designs from IKEA, and the rise of specialized gaming chairs. The article highlights how the chair has transcended its original purpose of royal distinction to become a ubiquitous, invisible part of daily life, while still maintaining its cultural significance. Through its journey, the chair has been influenced by industrial design, like the iconic Thonet chair, and continues to adapt to contemporary needs, from comfort to aesthetics. The chair's story is a r

item.title: Nvidia Reports Strong Q3 Earnings, Exceeds Estimates with AI Chip Sales Surge
item.description: Nvidia reported a stellar third-quarter performance, exceeding both revenue and earnings expectations. The company forecasted fourth-quarter revenue of $65 billion, surpassing Wall Street's $62 billion estimate. Nvidia's growth was primarily driven by an explosive demand for AI chips, especially for its Blackwell and cloud GPUs, with CEO Jensen Huang declaring that the AI ecosystem is scaling rapidly across industries and regions. For Q3, Nvidia posted earnings per share of $1.30 on $57.01 billion in revenue, significantly outperforming the analyst consensus of $1.26 per share and $55.2 billion in revenue. The data center segment generated $51.2 billion in revenue, surpassing expectations, while gaming revenue slightly missed estimates at $4.3 billion. Despite concerns from investor Michael Burry about the AI sector's sustainability, Nvidia's impressive performance and continued market dominance in AI chip technology highlight the company's role as a key player in the growing AI landsc

item.title: Mexico Partners with Barcelona to Build Largest Supercomputer in Latin America
item.description: Mexico has taken a significant step toward establishing its first continental-class supercomputer, as the federal government signed an agreement with the Barcelona Supercomputing Center (BSC). The ambitious project, announced on November 19, 2025, aims to build the largest supercomputer in Latin America, enabling Mexican scientists to access world-class computing infrastructure while developing domestic capabilities. Beginning in January 2026, Mexican researchers will gain access to MareNostrum 5, a supercomputer capable of performing 314 trillion operations per second, which will dramatically speed up research processes across various fields. The collaboration with BSC serves as an interim solution while Mexico builds its own infrastructure over the next 2-3 years. The project is expected to address critical needs in areas such as climate prediction, fiscal analysis, and satellite data processing. Furthermore, the initiative includes a robust educational component, training researcher

item.title: Russian Forces Near Capture of Key Ukrainian Industrial Complex
item.description: The NKMZ factory, located in the Donbas region of Ukraine, is one of Europe's largest heavy engineering plants, capable of manufacturing everything from submarine parts to turbines and ammunition. Founded in 1934, it became a key part of the Soviet industrial plan, contributing to wartime reconstruction and industrial power. Before the 2022 war, NKMZ accounted for 15% of Ukraine's GDP, with its products used for military and industrial purposes. Currently, the factory plays a critical role in supporting Ukraine's armed forces by producing ammunition and repairing armored vehicles. If captured by Russian forces, NKMZ would deprive Ukraine of a vital strategic asset, impacting the military's operational capacity and rapid response capabilities on the frontlines. The factory, which employs over 5,600 workers, remains operational, producing high-caliber shells and parts for military vehicles. Its capture would be a significant blow to Ukraine's military-industrial complex, further intensif

item.title: Blue Origin Unveils New Heavy-Lift Rocket: The New Glenn 9×4
item.description: Blue Origin has unveiled its new heavy-lift rocket, the New Glenn 9×4, just days after launching its second New Glenn rocket and successfully recovering its first stage. The New Glenn 9×4 is named for the number of engines in each stage—9 BE-4 engines powered by methane in the first stage and 4 BE-3U engines using hydrogen in the second. With this new configuration, the New Glenn 9×4 offers impressive payload capabilities, including the ability to carry 70 tons to Low Earth Orbit (LEO), 14 tons to Geosynchronous Orbit (GEO), and 20 tons to the Moon (TLI), significantly surpassing the current New Glenn 7×2’s 45 tons to LEO. This powerful new rocket also features a 8.7-meter-diameter fairing, an upgrade from the previous 7-meter diameter. The New Glenn 9×4 now competes with SpaceX’s Falcon Heavy in both payload and useful volume, though it has a similar design to the Chinese Long March CZ-10. Additionally, Blue Origin has announced improvements to its BE-4 and BE-3U engines, increasing t

item.title: Joe Rogan critiques Trump’s changing stance on Epstein files and shares past thoughts on buying notorious island
item.description: In a recent podcast, Joe Rogan mocked Donald Trump for his inconsistent approach to the Epstein case, calling out his sudden shift in stance on releasing Epstein's files. Rogan pointed out Trump’s previous claims that there were no files, and now, Trump supports the release of the documents. The back-and-forth came after Trump, in a post on Truth Social, reversed his position, urging House Republicans to vote to release the Epstein files. The bill passed in both the House and Senate, and Trump has indicated he would sign it. Rogan, a popular figure known for his candid commentary, also revealed that he once considered purchasing one of Jeffrey Epstein’s infamous properties, Little Saint James, a private island in the U.S. Virgin Islands. Although the deal didn’t go through, Rogan shared that they briefly entertained the idea due to the island's exorbitant price tag. The comedian’s comments reflect the ongoing media fascination with Epstein’s case, and his own complex relationship with

item.title: France's Insect-Eating Bird Populations Show Early Signs of Recovery Following Pesticide Ban
item.description: A study has found early signs of recovery in France's insect-eating bird populations after the EU's 2018 ban on neonicotinoid pesticides, which are known to harm bees and other pollinators. Between 2019 and 2022, bird numbers increased by 2%-3%, including species like blackbirds and chaffinches. The research, which analyzed over 1,900 sites across France, showed that areas where neonicotinoid use was banned saw 12% higher populations of insect-eating birds. The study is the first of its kind to track wildlife recovery across Europe after the pesticide ban, though further research is needed in other EU countries to confirm whether the findings hold more broadly. Despite this positive sign, experts caution that a full recovery will take decades, as neonicotinoids persist in soils. The research also highlights the broader impacts of pesticides on ecosystems, with the potential for positive effects on other insect-eating species such as mammals and bats. Experts argue that more sustainable

item.title: UN Security Council Supports US Plan for Gaza, Raising Concerns of a New Colonial Mandate
item.description: On November 17, 2025, the UN Security Council approved a resolution endorsing President Trump's plan for Gaza, a move that has raised alarm about the imposition of a 'colonial mandate' on Palestine. The resolution passed with 13 votes in favor and two abstentions from China and Russia, and reinstates a colonial oversight model similar to the League of Nations mandate system post-World War I. Under the new plan, Gaza is to be managed by a 'Peace Council' with a transitional administration overseeing reconstruction efforts. An International Stabilization Force (ISF) will be deployed in Gaza under a unified command, with troops contributed by several nations in cooperation with Egypt and Israel. Critics, including Hamas, have denounced the resolution, calling it a violation of Palestinian sovereignty and the beginning of a new occupation. The plan also calls for the demilitarization of Gaza, which has sparked fears of military conflict between the ISF and Hamas. While the resolution stres

item.title: Trump Accuses Democratic Lawmakers of Sedition After Urging Military to Defy Illegal Orders
item.description: Former President Donald Trump has publicly accused six Democratic lawmakers of seditious behavior after they released a video urging military and intelligence community personnel to refuse unlawful orders. The lawmakers, including Senators Elissa Slotkin and Mark Kelly, and Representatives Jason Crow, Chrissy Houlahan, Maggie Goodlander, and Chris Deluzio, all of whom have military or national security backgrounds, emphasized that the Constitution permits military personnel to reject illegal commands. In their video, they warned that the Trump administration was undermining trust in the military by politicizing it and urged service members to stand firm in defending the Constitution. Trump's response on social media was swift and harsh, calling for the lawmakers' arrests, and even suggesting they should face the death penalty for their alleged sedition. His posts included re-shares of extremist comments calling for the lawmakers to be hanged, which prompted widespread backlash. While s

item.title: Over 30,000 North Carolina Students Miss School Amid ICE Raids
item.description: In Charlotte-Mecklenburg County, North Carolina, over 30,000 students were reported absent from school on November 17, 2025. This surge in absenteeism comes amid an increase in ICE (Immigration and Customs Enforcement) raids under 'Operation Charlotte's Web.' The operation, which began on November 15, 2025, resulted in more than 200 detentions, mostly targeting businesses and public areas in the region. The school district, Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools (CMS), confirmed that the absentee rate was over 30,000 students, with a significant portion of the district’s population identifying as Hispanic. Local authorities, including Charlotte Mayor Vi Lyles, have criticized the ICE operation, urging federal agents to focus on violent criminals instead of everyday citizens. Despite this, CMS has stated that schools would remain open, and there had been no reports of immigration enforcement on school grounds. Governor Josh Stein and other state leaders have condemned the raids, emphasizing the

item.title: Mexico's November Protests Linked to Right-Wing Influence and Foreign Interference
item.description: The protests that erupted across Mexico on November 15, 2025, initially framed as a grassroots uprising led by Gen Z against government corruption, have been revealed to have ties to wealthy oligarchs and international right-wing actors. A new report by Infodemia claims that the demonstrations were funded and coordinated by a network of opposition figures and social media influencers, including Carlos Bello, a lifestyle influencer turned political activist. The protests, which spread across over 50 cities and left around 120 people injured, were also amplified by bot networks on platforms like Twitter and TikTok. Despite presenting themselves as apolitical, many of the key figures behind the protests have close ties to opposition parties and figures who have historically opposed the current Mexican government under President Claudia Sheinbaum. The protests gained significant international attention, with some media outlets portraying them as a youth-led rebellion, while others, includi

item.title: The Role of Amnesty in the Fight Against Fascism in Spain
item.description: The article highlights the historical and current significance of amnesty in the fight against fascism in Spain. It discusses how the amnesty, initially a demand from antifascist movements since the end of Franco's dictatorship in 1939, was not fully implemented after his death. Instead, the transition period was marked by repression against those who resisted the continuation of the fascist legacy. The author argues that the amnesty granted in 1977 did not address the real needs for justice and repair, leaving many political prisoners imprisoned and continuing to shield fascist perpetrators from accountability. Today, 50 years later, the repression has expanded to wider sectors of the popular movement, and the article calls for a total amnesty, recognition of rights, and reparations for antifascists who have suffered under fascist rule. It emphasizes that true justice cannot be achieved by simply removing symbolic medals or disregarding the pain of those oppressed. The fight for total

item.title: EU Involvement in Corruption Scandals Surrounding Ukraine
item.description: The European Union has been caught up in a growing corruption scandal related to the financial aid it sends to Ukraine. While the EU continues to send billions in support, concerns are rising about how the funds are misused by Zelensky's inner circle. Despite the public scandal and ongoing investigations into corrupt practices, EU officials appear to downplay the seriousness of the issue. The situation is further complicated by internal divisions, with some in the EU emphasizing the need to combat corruption while others are accused of defending corrupt officials for the sake of political stability. The EU's role in Ukraine's financial aid is now under scrutiny, as it's suggested that certain European figures may be benefiting from the misappropriation of funds. This scandal is not just about Ukrainian corruption but also exposes deeper issues of political favoritism and complicity within European institutions.

item.title: CGT convoca manifestaciones en España por los 78 años de la partición de Palestina
